2. A 5-year-old girl presented to the emergency department with persistent cough, difficulty swallowing, and hoarseness lasting for three weeks. Her parents reported decreased appetite and frequent nighttime choking episodes. Physical examination revealed mild tachypnea, stridor, and a palpable supraclavicular lymph node. A chest radiograph demonstrated an enlarged mediastinum, and CT scan identified a heterogeneous mass in the posterior mediastinum compressing the trachea. Urinary catecholamine metabolites, including elevated VMA and HVA, were noted on laboratory analysis. There were no signs of bone pain or neurological deficits. A biopsy of the mediastinal mass confirmed neuroblastoma with favorable histology. She was admitted for further staging and multidisciplinary management including chemotherapy.
